comment: White threw away his advantage with this move. 29. Rf8 Kxh6 30. h4 would have paralyzed black, and white would have all the time he needed to work on his own plans. reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by white, as the move 29. Rf8 allowed black to capture the rook with Kxh6, giving black an advantage. The subsequent move 30. h4 would have put pressure on black's position, but unfortunately, it was not played.

comment: This was a serious error by white. White's only plus is his king-side pawn majority, so he should've looked for a way to mobilize them. The way to do that was 33. Rf5+ Ke7 34. g5, which would make it a lot harder for black. Notice black couldn't even have tried 34. ... Rf8? in that variation, because white's pawns are too fast. e.g., 34. ... Rf8 35. g6! Rxf5 36. gxh7 Rf8 37. Ng6+ Kf7 38. Nxf8, and black can't stop white from playing h8Q. This illustrates the power of the advanced, passed pawns.
reasoning: The comment effectively explains the mistake made by the player, highlighting the missed opportunity to activate the king-side pawns for a stronger position.
